1. Fundamentals of Functions

Definition of a Function

A function is a mapping that assigns exactly one element of the codomain to each element of the domain. Functions can be viewed as mathematical machines that convert input values into output values.

$f: D \rightarrow W, x \mapsto fx$

Example: fx = 2x + 1

Domain D = ‚Ñù (all real numbers)

Range W = ‚Ñù

Image of x = 3: f(3) = 7

Important Terms

  • Domain D: Set of permissible x-values
  • Range W: Set of all possible y-values
  • Graph: Set of all points x,y where y = fx

Example: For fx = ‚àöx

Domain: D = [0,‚àû)

Range: W = [0,‚àû)

Graph: Parabola in the first quadrant

Function Properties

  • Injective: Each y-value occurs at most once
  • Surjective: Each y-value occurs at least once
  • Bijective: Function is both injective and surjective

Example: fx = x¬≤

Not injective: f(2) = f(-2) = 4

Not surjective: negative y-values are not reached

2. Important Function Types

Linear Functions

$fx = mx + b$

  • m: Slope
  • b: y-intercept

Example: fx = 2x - 3

Slope: m = 2

y-intercept: b = -3

Zero: x = 1.5

Quadratic Functions

$fx = ax^2 + bx + c$

  • a: Opening and stretching

3. Solving Equations

Linear Equations

Form: $ax + b = 0$

Solution: $x = -\frac{b}{a}$

Example: 3x + 6 = 0

3x = -6

x = -2

Quadratic Equations

Form: $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$

Solution formula: $x_{1,2} = -\frac{b}{2a} \pm \sqrt{\frac{b^2}{4a^2} - \frac{c}{a}}$

Example: x¬≤ - 5x + 6 = 0

a = 1, b = -5, c = 6

$x_{1,2} = \frac{5}{2} \pm \sqrt{\frac{25}{4} - 6}$

x‚ÇÅ = 3, x‚ÇÇ = 2

Form: $a \cdot b^x = c$

Solution: $x = \log_b\frac{c}{a}$

Example: 2 ¬∑ 3^x = 18

3^x = 9

4. Inequalities

Linear Inequalities

Form: $ax + b < 0$ or $ax + b > 0$

When dividing by a negative number: Flip the inequality sign!

Example: -2x + 4 > 0

-2x > -4

x < 2

Quadratic Inequalities

Form: $ax^2 + bx + c < 0$ or $ax^2 + bx + c > 0$

Solution using zeros and sign changes

Example: x¬≤ - 4 > 0

Zeros: x = ¬±2

Solution: x < -2 or x > 2

Absolute Value Inequalities

Form: $|ax + b| < c$ or $|ax + b| > c$

Solution by case distinction

Example: |x - 2| < 3

-3 < x - 2 < 3

-1 < x < 5
